title: Shuttered Nevada prison closer to being tourist attraction
text:

(AP Photo/Michelle Rindels) ADVERTISEMENT Shuttered Nevada prison closer to being tourist attraction Associated Press | 
CARSON CITY, Nev. — To see the Nevada State Prison in Carson City is to understand why lawmakers decided to shut it down three years ago. 
The site, which housed prisoners even before Nevada became a state about 150 years ago, features cramped cells, uneven walkways and the kind of blind spots that left corrections officers patrolling the yard nervous. 
But a group of history buffs, including some who once worked as guards there, sees the fossil-laden, sandstone-block structure as the next Alcatraz — a tourist attraction steeped in lore of prison breaks, Wild West personalities and outlaw antics. 
“From a correctional standpoint, it’s awful,” said Glen Whorton, a former prison guard and head of the prison’s preservation society. 
“But from a design standpoint, it’s awesome,” former guard Terry Hubert added. 
The Nevada State Prison Preservation Society scored a win this legislative session when lawmakers approved a bill that sets up a process for the state to designate portions of the 153-year-old complex for cultural use, establishes a funding mechanism and sets groundwork for eventual tours. 
But proponents acknowledge that the opening day of a functional museum is far off. 
Yet preservation advocates say the prison, which operated as the state’s only correctional institution until 1964, drips with historical appeal as the site of inmate escapes and the nation’s only prisoner-operated casino. Founded in 1862, a year after Nevada became a territory, the prison has housed everyone from mining boom-era “desperadoes” to card cheats from Las Vegas. 
The National Park Service is reviewing a lengthy application for the prison to be put on the National Register of Historic Places. 
If the prison opens to tours, it would join Alcatraz and other prisons in the U.S. that have become tourist attractions. 
“People are interested in prisons and want to see the inside of them,” said Sean Kelley, senior vice president at the Eastern State Penitentiary Historic Site in Philadelphia, which draws about 400,000 visitors a year.
